oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Minutes of the Park Hill Action Committee (PHAC) from a meeting held on September 22, 1966 in Denver, Colorado. The minutes include the report on the Denver Fair Housing Center, cooperation with Colorado Woman's College, a Park Hill conservation plan, and a new philosophy and corresponding programs in city government to keep older neighborhoods from deteriorating. Minutes of the Board of Governors' meeting immediately following the general meeting report the unanimous election of the nominating committee's list of the officers and delegates of the PHAC's Board for the following year. Also included is a report of an October 10, 1966 follow-up committee meeting concerning publicity for the conservation plan.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Park Hill Action Committee: A Study of the Legitimation Process of Community Involvement
Greater Park Hill Community, Incorporated Records
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Citizens' associations
Race relations
African Americans
Park Hill Action Committee
Dissertations, Academic
South Park Hill (Denver, Colo.)
Denver (Colo.)
Colorado
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Masters' thesis in sociology covering the Park Hill Action Committee, a community improvement organization in Denver, Colorado. The thesis analyzes the process by which the work of the committee was accepted by the residents of the community and recognized to be worthy of voluntary involvement. The author's main focus in analyzing the legitimation of the committee was the committee's involvement in issues related to race relations during the period examined. Thesis (M.A.) -- University of Colorado, Boulder, Colorado.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Minutes of the Park Hill Action Committee (PHAC) from a meeting held on June 29, 1964 at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in Denver, Colorado. The Human Relations Committee reported on a meeting with the City Council from the previous month, where Spanish-Americans and African-Americans ("Negroes" in the original document) aired multiple grievances, which led to a meeting the following month in the Governor's office concerning fair housing and fair employment for minority groups. The Real Estate Committee reported on a recently conducted census which indicated that 400 African-American families resided in the Park Hill neighborhood, in certain areas, consisting of up to 37% of the neighborhood population.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Minutes of the Park Hill Action Committee (PHAC) from a meeting held on April 5, 1967 in Denver, Colorado. Delegates present at the meeting include: Hank Job, Mike Quering, Doris Shultz, John Shofstal, Al Eckhardt, Howard Phillips, Bob Hickman, Tom Lewallen, Richard Tumpes, Art Branscombe, Jay Bollinger, Fran LeDuke, Lois Weber, Jules Mondschein, Fred Thomas, Gerald Kopel, and Marge McLaughlin. The minutes primarily cover proposed City Council redistricting, its effects on the Park Hill neighborhood, and the possibilities of filing a civil suit to prevent the redistricting, with the support of the PHAC. Also discussed: zoning, a new airport runway, schools, youth recreation and parks.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Minutes of the Park Hill Action Committee (PHAC) from a meeting held on November 4, 1968 in Denver, Colorado. Issues under discussion include: joint community endeavors between the PHAC and Temple Buell College, the building of facilities for youth recreation, the efforts of the PHAC on behalf of quality integrated schools, and the racial integration of the Park Hill neighborhood. The report of the PHAC Schools sub-committee deals with the issues related to the implementation of the Noel Resolution, a 1968 resolution presented to the Denver Public School (DPS) system that asked the superintendent to develop a plan to integrate the city's schools. The report of the sub-committees on Youth and Recreation, Block Workers, Zoning, and the Membership and Treasurers' reports are also included.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Minutes of the Board of Governors of the Park Hill Action Committee (PHAC) from a meeting held on June 29, 1964 at the Montview Presbyterian Church in Denver, Colorado. Zoning was discussed, in specific, the issue of the yards of vacant houses where the real estate companies responsible had not provided proper upkeep and allowed the yards to become "eyesores." The letters of complaint to the companies are included with the minutes. Traffic congestion and truck traffic from Colorado Boulevard was mentioned as an issue. Phil Wilcox, the Chairman of Real Estate, made mention of a survey of houses that changed owners twice in the last year. The reports of the PHAC's Blockworker Organization, Membership Sub-Committee, Treasurer's Report, and Report of the 14th Annual Summer Workshop in Leadership Development and Subsequent Recommendations for PHAC are also included.

"1964" handwritten addition to title. "Improvement" stricken from "Cranmer Park Improvement Association" and replaced with "Civic." "Boy" stricken and replaced with "boy or girl" in "A boy or girl may register at any time." "Human" stricken from "Mayor's Commission on Human Relations" and replaced with "Community."

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Minutes of the Park Hill Action Committee (PHAC) from a meeting held on March 2, 1961 in Montview Presbyterian Church in Denver, Colorado. Some issues under discussion include: the incorporation of the Park Hill Action Committee, and statistics on the ratio of African-American to Caucasian home-buyers for sales of homes north of 26th Avenue, from Colorado Boulevard to Monaco. Also attached: a resolution of the PHAC encouraging residents not to discriminate based on race or ethnicity, to "forswear panicky selling when a Negro family moves into the new neighborhood, and to welcome their new neighbor as they would welcome any other family," as well as a fact sheet for PHAC "blockworkers."
